awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Collaborative Research: Matrix Signings and Algorithms for Expanders and Combinatorial Nullstellensatz
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate spectral properties of graph-related matrices and their signings, which have become fundamental tools in computer science. The spectra of such matrices have had a tremendous impact in numerous areas including machine learning, data mining, web search and ranking, game theory, scientific computing, and computer vision and have influenced several algorithmic innovations. The project will have significant technical as well as educational impacts. The inherent mathematical and algorithmic nature of the project together with the plethora of potential practical applications will bring together researchers from varied areas such as mathematics and network design. The investigators will organize a workshop on Spectral Graph Theory to bring together experts in these areas. The project will support graduate students who will receive mentoring and extensive training in the design and analysis of algorithms. The investigators will also direct special efforts towards fostering diversity through educational activities targeting under-represented groups in STEM disciplines.

In this project, the investigators will design efficient algorithms for constructing various combinatorial structures that are guaranteed to exist through suitable signings of matrices. The combinatorial structures to be studied include expander graphs and several other applications of the algebraic method. Notably, the algorithmic problem of efficiently constructing of expander graphs is at the core of spectral graph theory. This project will develop a comprehensive understanding of the inherent difficulties, as well as propose algorithms for efficiently constructing expander graphs via signed adjacency matrices. Combinatorial Nullstellensatz is a powerful algebraic tool often used to show the existence of certain combinatorial structures. However, the non-constructive nature of its proof has been a barrier towards finding these structures efficiently. Existential proofs based on the algebraic method have resisted progress on the constructive front (unlike those based on probabilistic method). In this project, the investigators will break ground along this direction by obtaining efficient constructive proofs for restricted applications of Combinatorial Nullstellensatz.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project was focused on two main topics:

1) Matrix Signings, Expander graphs, and Cuts in graphs

The major goals in network design are to support high capacity and to be fault tolerant. Road networks should carry many vehicles with minimal congestion, and communication networks should deliver gigabits of data per second to the clients. At the same time, failure of some links should not result in global network failure. When modeling networks with graphs, expansion is the graph propetry that translates being well-connected.The larger the expansion, the better the network capacity and fault-tolerance, since expander graphs do not have partitions (cuts) with very few edges between them. In this project, we studied properties of graph related matrices, such as signings, and how those relate with different notions of expansion. We showed that certain matrix properties related to signings imply expansion properties of the underlying graphs. We also studied several questions related to graph partitions, such as Maximum Cut, and provided bounds for those quantities for general classes of graphs.

 

2) Smoothed Analysis on Graph Cut problems.

Expanding upon our study of cuts and related notions to graph expansion, we studied variants of these problems, where one is required to only find a local optimum. We developed both classical and quantum algorithms to find such local optima, focusing on the problem of Local Max Cut. On the classical side, we improved upon the state of the art known algorithms for smoothed analysis of Local Max Cut. On the quantum side, with the advent of quantum computers, the question of whether can achieve quantum supremacy rears its head: is there an advantage that we gain by using quantum algorithms to any classical algorithm? Most importatly, is there any advantage that the limited power of current quantum computers can achieve? We show that for classes of algorithms used in today's feasible quantum computers, no such advantage can be gained over simple classical algorithms for Local Max Cut, and expanded our study to several other cut related problems.
